alert.note: Alert for Island; San Juan (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued December 24 at 8:59AM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...THREAT OF URBAN AND RIVER RIVER FLOODING THROUGH EARLY NEXT WEEK ACROSS WESTERN WASHINGTON... A series of storm systems will bring moderate to heavy precipitation and a rapid warm-up through the weekend into next week. The first round of moderate to heavy rainfall will occur today with snow levels rising to 6000 to 7000 feet. Additional enhancement of runoff and impacts may result from rain falling on existing snow - including urban flooding concerns as drainage systems may not be able to keep up with the increased runoff from the rain and the melting snow. Rises are expected on all area rivers. However widespread flooding is not expected through Sunday night at this time. Additional moderate to heavy rainfall early next week is expected as a series of atmospheric rivers may take aim at the Pacific Northwest. Each of these potentially wet systems are lined up to impact the region every 24 hours or so. This could lead to additional river flooding, especially with snow levels likely remaining elevated with these warm and moist weather systems. This will lead to progressively higher flows through at least the first part of next week. Confidence remains somewhat low in pinpointing any particular basins for early next week due to the complex evolution of the pattern and the uncertainty of the impact of snowmelt, combined with heavy rain and warming. The next update will be provided by 10:00 AM Sunday, December 25. Please monitor the latest river forecasts from the National Weather Service for additional information.
